Ink.Net.Ajax.name: Ink.Net.Ajax
Ink.Net.Ajax.description: Creates a new cross browser XMLHttpRequest object

props.name: asynchronous
props.description: if the request should be asynchronous. true by default.

props.name: cors
props.description: set this to true if you're doing a cross-origin request

props.name: method
props.description: HTTP request method. POST by default.

props.name: parameters
props.description: Request parameters which should be sent with the request

props.name: timeout
props.description: Request timeout

props.name: delay
props.description: Artificial delay. If request is completed in time lower than this, then wait a bit before calling the callbacks

props.name: postBody
props.description: POST request body. If not specified, it's filled with the contents from parameters

props.name: contentType
props.description: Content-type header to be sent. Defaults to 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'

props.name: requestHeaders
props.description: key-value pairs for additional request headers

props.name: onComplete
props.description: Callback executed after the request is completed, no matter what happens during the request.

props.name: onSuccess
props.description: Callback executed if the request is successful (requests with 2xx status codes)

props.name: onFailure
props.description: Callback executed if the request fails (requests with status codes different from 2xx)

props.name: onException
props.description: Callback executed if an exception  occurs. Receives the exception as a parameter.

props.name: onCreate
props.description: Callback executed after object initialization but before the request is made

props.name: onInit
props.description: Callback executed before any initialization

props.name: onTimeout
props.description: Callback executed if the request times out

props.name: evalJS
props.description: If the request Content-type header is application/json, evaluates the response and populates responseJSON. Use 'force' if you want to force the response evaluation, no matter what Content-type it's using. Defaults to true.

props.name: sanitizeJSON
props.description: Sanitize the content of responseText before evaluation

props.name: xhrProxy
props.description:
URI for proxy service hosted on the same server as the web app, that can fetch documents from other domains.
                                            The service must pipe all input and output untouched (some input sanitization is allowed, like clearing cookies).
                                            e.g., requesting http://example.org/doc can become /proxy/http%3A%2F%2Fexample.org%2Fdoc The proxy service will
                                            be used for cross-domain requests, if set, else a network error is returned as exception.

Ink.Net.JsonP.name: Ink.Net.JsonP
Ink.Net.JsonP.description:
This class takes care of the nitty-gritty details of doing jsonp requests: Storing
a callback in a globally accessible manner, waiting for the timeout or completion
of the request, and passing extra GET parameters to the server, is not so complicated
but it's boring and repetitive to code and tricky to get right.

props.name: onFailure

props.name: params
props.description: object with the parameters and respective values to unfold

props.name: callbackParam
props.description: parameter to use as callback. defaults to 'jsoncallback'

props.name: internalCallback
props.description: *Advanced*: name of the callback function stored in the Ink.Net.JsonP object.

Ink.UI.Close.name: Ink.UI.Close
Ink.UI.Close.description:
Subscribes clicks on the document.body. If and only if you clicked on an element
having class "ink-close" or "ink-dismiss", will go up the DOM hierarchy looking for an element with any
of the following classes: "ink-alert", "ink-alert-block".
If it is found, it is removed from the DOM.

One should call close once per page (full page refresh).
example:
<script>
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.UI.Close_1'],function( Close ){
            new Close();
        });
    </script>

Ink.UI.Stacker_1.name: Ink.UI.Stacker_1
Ink.UI.Stacker_1.description:
This module combines several stacks of items together, in smaller screen sizes.

The purpose is to have several stacks of items which may have different heights and as such cannot be used because of `float: left` quirks.

For example, when you have three different columns of information:

    [col. A: 1] [col. B: 1] [col. C: 1]
    [col. B: 2] [col. C: 2] [col. C: 2]

and the screen resizes and you need a layout of 2 columns, Stacker reorders the stacks so that you get:

    [col. A: 1] [col. B: 1]
    [col. C: 1] [col. A: 2]
    [col. B: 2] [col. C: 2]

Note: If you just want to use a different amount of columns for your items in several viewports, but these items are guaranteed to have a fixed height, don't use this module. Use the `small-*`, `medium-*` and `large-*` classes instead.

params.name: container
params.description: Element which contains the stacks (identified by the options.column selector)

props.name: column
props.description: Select the columns inside the `container`

props.name: item
props.description: Select items in your stack

props.name: customBreakPoints
props.description: options for each breakpoint name. Use this if you have more breakpoints than Ink by default (`large`, `medium`, `small`)

props.name: customBreakpoints.(breakpoint).max
props.description: Maximum screen size as seen in your media query

props.name: customBreakpoints.(breakpoint).min
props.description: Minimum screen size as seen in your media query

props.name: customBreakpoints.(breakpoint).cols
props.description: Column count for this size.

props.name: largeMax
props.description: Upper bound of `large` breakpoint

props.name: largeMin
props.description: Lower bound of `large` breakpoint

props.name: mediumMax
props.description: Upper bound of `medium` breakpoint

props.name: mediumMin
props.description: Lower bound of `medium` breakpoint

props.name: smallMax
props.description: Upper bound of `small` breakpoint

props.name: smallMin
props.description: Lower bound of `small` breakpoint

props.name: largeCols
props.description: Number of columns in the `large` viewport

props.name: mediumCols
props.description: Number of columns in the `medium` viewport

props.name: smallCols
props.description: Number of columns in the `small` viewport

props.name: isOrdered
props.description: When `false`, do not reorder stacks when combining them.

props.name: onRunCallback
props.description: Called when instantiated

props.name: onResizeCallback
props.description: Called when resized because the window resized.

props.name: onAPIReloadCallback
props.description: Called when you ask to reload stack items from the DOM.

Ink.UI.Sticky.name: Ink.UI.Sticky
Ink.UI.Sticky.description:
The Sticky component takes an element and transforms it's behavior in order to, when the user scrolls he sets its position
to fixed and maintain it until the user scrolls back to the same place.

props.name: offsetBottom
props.description: Number of pixels of distance from the bottomElement.

props.name: offsetTop
props.description: Number of pixels of distance from the topElement.

props.name: inlineDimensions
props.description: Whether to set "style.height" and "style.width" in the stuck element. Turn this off when your `stickyClass` has its own height and width and you don't want this to be dealt with through javascript.

props.name: inlinePosition
props.description: Whether to set "style.left" in the stuck element. Turn this off when your `stickyClass` has its own "left" position and you don't want this to be dealt with through javascript.

props.name: wrapperClass
props.description: Css class for the wrapper element.

props.name: stickyClass
props.description: Css class for sticking the sticky to the screen. Add your own "stuck" class to define your own sticky behaviour.

props.name: topElement
props.description: CSS Selector that specifies a top element with which the component could collide.

props.name: bottomElement
props.description: CSS Selector that specifies a bottom element with which the component could collide.

props.name: activateInLayouts
props.description: Layouts in which the sticky behaviour is present. Pass an array or comma-separated string.

example:
<script>
         Ink.requireModules( ['Ink.Dom.Selector_1','Ink.UI.Sticky_1'], function( Selector, Sticky ) {
             var menuElement = Ink.s('#menu');
             var stickyObj = new Sticky( menuElement );
         });
     </script>

Ink.UI.Swipe.name: Ink.UI.Swipe
Ink.UI.Swipe.description:
Subscribe swipe gestures!

Supports filtering swipes be any combination of the criteria supported in the options.

props.name: onEnd
props.description: callback function for the `touchend` event. Gets all the gesture information, and is filtered by min/max Dist and Duration options (see below)

props.name: onStart
props.description: callback function for `touchstart` event

props.name: onMove
props.description: callback function for every `touchmove` event. Gets current gesture information.

props.name: minDist
props.description: minimum allowed distance, in pixels

props.name: maxDist
props.description: maximum allowed distance, in pixels

props.name: minDuration
props.description: minimum allowed duration, in seconds

props.name: maxDuration
props.description: maximum allowed duration, in seconds

props.name: axis
props.description: if either 'x' or 'y' is passed, only swipes where the dominant axis is the given one trigger the callback

props.name: storeGesture
props.description: store gesture information and provide to the callback

props.name: stopEvents
props.description:
stop (default and propagation) of the received events

-----

Arguments received by the callbacks
-----------------------------------

`onStart`, `onMove`, and `onEnd` receive as argument an object containing:

  - `event`: the DOMEvent object
  - `element`: the target element
  - `Instance`: the `Ink.UI.Swipe_1` instance
  - `position`: `Array` with `[x, y]` coordinates of current position
  - `dt`: Time passed between now and the first event (onMove only)
  - `gesture`: an Array containing [x,y] coordinates of every touchmove event received (storeGesture only) (onEnd only)
  - `time`: an Array containing all the `dt` values for every touchmove event (onEnd only)
  - `overallMovement`: X and Y distance traveled by the touch movement (`[x, y]`) (onEnd only)
  - `overallTime`: total time passed (onEnd only)

Ink.UI.Table.name: Ink.UI.Table
Ink.UI.Table.description:
The Table component transforms the native/DOM table element into a
sortable, paginated component.

props.name: pageSize
props.description: Number of rows per page. Omit to avoid paginating.

props.name: endpoint
props.description: Endpoint to get the records via AJAX. Omit if you don't want to do AJAX

props.name: createEndpointUrl
props.description:
Callback to customise what URL the AJAX endpoint is at. Receives three
     arguments: base (the "endpoint" option), sort (`{ order: 'asc' or 'desc', field: fieldname }`)
     and page ({ page: page number, size: items per page })

props.name: getDataFromEndPoint
props.description:
Callback to allow the user to retrieve the data himself given an URL.
     Must accept two arguments: `url` and `callback`. This `callback` will
     take as a single argument a JavaScript object.

props.name: processJSONRows
props.description: Retrieve an array of rows from the data which came from AJAX.

props.name: processJSONHeaders
props.description:
Get an object with all the headers' names as keys, and a { label, sortable }
     object as value.
     Example: `{col1: {label: "Column 1"}, col2: {label: "Column 2", sortable: true}`.
     Takes a single argument, the JSON response.

props.name: processJSONRow
props.description: Process a row object before it gets on the table.

props.name: processJSONField
props.description:
Process the field data before putting it on the table.
     You can return HTML, a DOM element, or a string here.
     Arguments you receive: `(column, fieldData, rowIndex)`.

props.name: (field_name)
props.description: The same as processJSONField, but for a particular field.

props.name: processJSONTotalRows
props.description:
A callback where you have a chance to say how many rows
     are in the dataset (not only on this page) you have on the
     collection. You get as an argument the JSON response.

props.name: getSortKey
(field_name)
props.description: Same as `options.getSortKey`, but for a particular field.

Ink.UI.TagField.name: Ink.UI.TagField
Ink.UI.TagField.description:
Use this class to have a field where a user can input several tags into a single text field. A good example is allowing the user to describe a blog post or a picture through tags, for later searching.

The markup is as follows:

          <input class="ink-tagfield" type="text" value="initial,value">

By applying this UI class to the above input, you get a tag field with the tags "initial" and "value". The class preserves the original input element. It remains hidden and is updated with new tag information dynamically, so regular HTML form logic still applies.

Below "input" refers to the current value of the input tag (updated as the user enters text, of course), and "output" refers to the value which this class writes back to said input tag.

props.name: tags
props.description: initial tags in the input

props.name: allowRepeated
props.description: allow user to input several tags

props.name: separator
props.description: Split the input by this RegExp. The default splits by spaces, commas and semicolons

props.name: outSeparator
props.description: Use this string to separate each tag from the next in the output.

props.name: maxTags
props.description: Maximum amount of tags the user can write.

Ink.UI.Tooltip.name: Ink.UI.Tooltip

params.name: target
params.description: Target element or selector of elements, to display the tooltips on.

props.name: text
props.description: Text content for the tooltip.

props.description: HTML for the tooltip. Same as above, but won't escape HTML.

props.name: where
props.description: Positioning for the tooltip. Options:

props.name: up/down/left/right
props.description: Place above, below, to the left of, or to the right of, the target. Show an arrow.

props.name: mousemove
props.description: Place the tooltip to the bottom and to the right of the mouse when it hovers the element, and follow the mouse as it moves.

props.name: mousefix
props.description: Place the tooltip to the bottom and to the right of the mouse when it hovers the element, keep the tooltip there motionless.

props.name: color
props.description: Color of the tooltip. Options are red, orange, blue, green and black. Default is white.

props.name: fade
props.description: Fade time; Duration of the fade in/out effect.

props.name: forever
props.description: Set to 1/true to prevent the tooltip from being erased when the mouse hovers away from the target

props.name: timeout
props.description: Time for the tooltip to live. Useful together with [options.forever].

props.name: delay
props.description: Time the tooltip waits until it is displayed. Useful to avoid getting the attention of the user unnecessarily

props.name: template
props.description: Element or selector containing HTML to be cloned into the tooltips. Can be a hidden element, because CSS `display` is set to `block`.

props.name: templatefield
props.description: Selector within the template element to choose where the text is inserted into the tooltip. Useful when a wrapper DIV is required.

props.name: left,top
props.description: (Nitty-gritty) Spacing from the target to the tooltip, when `where` is `mousemove` or `mousefix`

props.name: spacing
props.description: (Nitty-gritty) Spacing between the tooltip and the target element, when `where` is `up`, `down`, `left`, or `right`

classitems.description:
Bean maintains an internal registry for event listeners. We don't touch elements, objects
or functions to identify them, instead we store everything in the registry.
Each event listener has a RegEntry object, we have one 'registry' for the whole instance.
Public API: off(), on(), add(), (remove()), one(), fire(), clone()
off(element[, eventType(s)[, handler ]])
on(element, eventType(s)[, selector], handler[, args ])

add(element[, selector], eventType(s), handler[, args ])

Deprecated: kept (for now) for backward-compatibility
one(element, eventType(s)[, selector], handler[, args ])

fire(element, eventType(s)[, args ])

The optional 'args' argument must be an array, if no 'args' argument is provided
then we can use the browser's DOM event system, otherwise we trigger handlers manually

clone(dstElement, srcElement[, eventType ])

TODO: perhaps for consistency we should allow the same flexibility in type specifiers?

Keep this declaration here and off Bean as it extends the Event
object and some properties are readonly in strict mode
Instantiate browser native events array

Returns a function which calls `func`, waiting at least `wait`
milliseconds between calls. This is useful for events such as `scroll`
or `resize`, which can be triggered too many times per second, slowing
down the browser with needless function calls.

*note:* This does not delay the first function call to the function.
classitems.name: throttle

params.description: Function to call. Arguments and context are both passed.

classitems.description:
Serializes a form into an object, turning field names into keys, and field values into values.

note: Multi-select and checkboxes with multiple values will yield arrays
classitems.name: serialize

return.description: map of fieldName -> String|String[]|Boolean

params.name: form
params.description: form element from which the extraction is to occur

example:
<form id="frm">
        <input type="text" name="field1">
        <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.Dom.FormSerialize_1', 'Ink.Dom.Event_1'], function (FormSerialize, InkEvent) {
            InkEvent.observe('frm', 'submit', function (event) {
                var formData = FormSerialize.serialize('frm'); // -> {field1:"123"}
                InkEvent.stop(event);
            });
        });
    </script>

classitems.description:
Sets form elements's values with values given from object

One cannot restore the values of an input with `type="file"` (browser prohibits it)
classitems.name: fillIn

params.name: form
params.description: form element which is to be populated

example:
<form id="frm">
        <input type="text" name="field1">
        <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        Ink.requireModules(['Ink.Dom.FormSerialize_1'], function (FormSerialize) {
            var values = {field1: 'CTHULHU'};
            FormSerialize.fillIn('frm', values);
            // At this point the form is pre-filled with the values above.
        });
    </script>

classitems.description:
Get options from an "options" object and the Element's data attributes.

The element's data attributes take precedence.

Values from the element's data-atrributes are coerced into the required type.

Mainly for Ink UI.* modules
classitems.name: options

params.name: defaults
params.description: Object with arrays of option defaults

params.name: overrides
params.description: Object containing options given from user through JavaScript

example:
this._options = Ink.UI.Common.options('MyComponent', {
         'anobject': ['Object', null],  // Defaults to null
         'target': ['Element', null],
         'stuff': ['Number', 0.1],
         'stuff2': ['Integer', 0],
         'doKickFlip': ['Boolean', false],
         'targets': ['Elements'], // Required option since no default was given
         'onClick': ['Function', null]
     }, options || {}, elm)

### Note about booleans

Here is how options are read from the markup
data-attributes, for several values`data-a-boolean`.

Options considered true:

  - `data-a-boolean="true"`
  - (Every other value which is not on the list below.)

Options considered false:

  - `data-a-boolean="false"`
  - `data-a-boolean=""`
  - `data-a-boolean`

Options which go to default:

  - (no attribute). When `data-a-boolean` is ommitted, the
  option is not considered true nor false, and as such
  defaults to what is in the `defaults` argument.

DRY base for a function which tries to get the next or previous valid year or month.

It checks if we can go forward by using _dateCmp with atomic
precision (this means, {_year} for leaping years, and
{_year, month} for leaping months), then it tries to get the
result from the user-supplied callback (nextDateFn or prevDateFn),
and when this is not present, advance the date forward using the
`advancer` callback.

classitems.description:
Makes an element droppable and adds it to the stack of droppable elements.
Can consider it a constructor of droppable elements, but where no Droppable object is returned.

In the following arguments, any events/callbacks you may pass, can be either functions or strings. If the 'move' or 'copy' strings are passed, the draggable gets moved into this droppable. If 'revert' is passed, an acceptable droppable is moved back to the element it came from.

props.description: Selector for choosing draggables which can be dropped in this droppable.

props.name: onHover
props.description: callback called when an acceptable draggable element is hovering the droppable. Gets the draggable and the droppable element as parameters.

props.name: onDrop
props.description: callback called when an acceptable draggable element is dropped. Gets the draggable, the droppable and the event as parameters.

props.name: onDropOut
props.description: callback called when a droppable is dropped outside this droppable. Gets the draggable, the droppable and the event as parameters. (see above for string options).

example:
## What markup do I need? Besides the markup structure you can see in , you need to add the `ink-fv-*` classes to your inputs, which correspond to validation rules in this component. Available classes are: - `ink-fv-required` : Required field - `ink-fv-email` : Valid e-mail - `ink-fv-url` : Valid URL address - `ink-fv-number` : Valid number - `ink-fv-phone_pt`, `ink-fv-phone_cv`, `ink-fv-phone_mz`, `ink-fv-phone_ao` : Valid telephone number in Portugal, Cape Verde, Mozambique or Angola. - `ink-fv-date` : Valid date - `ink-fv-confirm` : Make the user type the same thing twice. Common rule for confirming passwords. - `ink-fv-custom` : Custom rule (see below example "Custom rule") E-mail field:
Phone number field:
Website field (optional): ## Simple usage So you have a form and would like to validate it? This example shows how to validate a form and stop it from being submitted when invalid. To use this, add the several ink-fv-* classes to your input elements. The validate() function will also add "invalid" classes to each of your elements so the user gets a color feedback and an error message below each element (control-group, really). var myForm = Ink.i('my-form'); InkEvent.observe(myForm, 'submit', function (ev) { var formIsValid = FormValidator.validate(myForm); if (!formIsValid) { InkEvent.stop(ev); // Cancel submission of form. } });

example:
_('Gosto muito de {} e o cu  {}.', 'carros', 'azul');
     // returns 'Gosto muito de carros e o cu  azul.'

_('O {1}  {2} como {2}  a cor do {3}.', 'carro', 'azul', 'FCP');
     // returns 'O carro  azul como azul  o FCP.'

_('O {person1} dava-se com a {person2}', {person1: 'coisinho', person2: 'coisinha'});

classitems.description:
Returns the ordinal suffix of `num` (For example, 1 > 'st', 2 > 'nd', 5 > 'th', ...).

This works by using transforms (in the form of Objects or Functions) passed into the
function or found in the special key `_ordinals` in the active language dictionary.
classitems.name: ordinal

params.name: options
params.description:
Maps for translating. Each of these options' fallback is found in the current
   language's dictionary. The lookup order is the following:
  
       1. `exceptions`
       2. `byLastDigit`
       3. `default`
  
   Each of these may be either an `Object` or a `Function`. If it's a function, it
   is called (with `number` and `digit` for any function except for byLastDigit,
   which is called with the `lastDigit` of the number in question), and if the
   function returns a string, that is used. If it's an object, the property is
   looked up using `[...]`. If what is found is a string, it is used.

props.name: byLastDigit
props.description:
If the language requires the last digit to be considered, mappings of last digits
   to ordinal suffixes can be created here.

props.name: exceptions
props.description: Map unique, special cases to their ordinal suffixes.

return.description: Ordinal suffix for `num`.

classitems.description:
Regular expression groups for several groups of characters

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C0_Controls_and_Basic_Latin
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_%28Unicode%29#Basic_Multilingual_Plane
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8859-1
classitems.name: _characterGroups

classitems.description: Create a regular expression for several character groups.
classitems.name: createRegExp

params.name: Groups...
params.description:
Groups to build regular expressions for. Possible keys are:

- **numbers**: 0-9
- **asciiAlpha**: a-z, A-Z
- **latin1Alpha**: asciiAlpha, plus printable characters in latin-1
- **unicodeAlpha**: unicode alphanumeric characters.
- **space**: ' ', the space character.
- **dash**: dash character.
- **underscore**: underscore character.
- **nicknamePunctuation**: dash, dot, underscore
- **singleLineWhitespace**: space and tab (whitespace which only spans one line).
- **newline**: newline character ('\n')
- **whitespace**: whitespace characters in the ASCII character set.
- **asciiPunctuation**: punctuation characters in the ASCII character set.
- **latin1Punctuation**: punctuation characters in latin-1.
- **unicodePunctuation**: punctuation characters in unicode.

Missing item type
DRY base for a function which tries to get the next or previous valid year or month.

It checks if we can go forward by using _dateCmp with atomic
precision (this means, {_year} for leaping years, and
{_year, month} for leaping months), then it tries to get the
result from the user-supplied callback (nextDateFn or prevDateFn),
and when this is not present, advance the date forward using the
`advancer` callback.
